bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert G. Love and J.F. Siler, November 4, 1952

div1.p: Hench requests that Love and Siler contact the editors of two military journals and encourage them to cover the dedication of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert G. Love and J.F. Siler, November 4, 1952
div1.opener:
November 4, 1952
General Albert Love
Colonel J. F. Siler
Washington, D. C.
Dear Friends:
div1.p:
So far as I know, the Cubans are going ahead with their plans to dedicate
Camp Lazear on Finlay's Birthday, which is “Physician's Day” in Havana, on
December 3. So far as I know, they are planning to invite officially cer-
tain Americans to attend the ceremony; however I know of no official in-
vitations as yet sent out, nor have I received one myself. I have merely
been told unofficially by Doctor Pedro Nogueira, the spark plug of the
movement, that I am to be invited and have been asked to speak for ten
minutes. Therefore I am planning to go, flying both ways and making a very
hasty trip.

I do think it is very important that the Cubans be permitted to know how
much this gesture on their part is appreciated and I hope there will be
some publicity about the dedication in the American press, certainly in
the medical press. In view of the fact that the major contributions were
made by American medical officers and military personnel. I think it is
most appropriate that the two military journals, THE MILITARY SURGEON and
the U. S. ARMED FORCES MEDICAL JOURNAL, both carry news items regarding
this.

Would it not be an excellent idea if the editors of both of these journals
were approached and told a little about it? Then I hope that they would
both write to Doctor Nogueira just as soon as possible and ask for some in-
formation to be published in each of these journals as a news item.

I do not want to impose upon you gentlemen but I wondered if, being in
Washington and probably knowing both of the editors, you would kindly get
in touch with these men at your earliest convenience. Col. James M. Phalon
is Editor of The MILITARY SURGEON and Col. Wayne G. Brandstadt is Editor-in-
Chief of the U. S. ARMED FORCES MEDICAL JOURNAL. I, in turn, am writing to
the editor of the J.A.M.A.

I think the two editors in Washington could open their letters something as
follows:
“Dear Doctor Nogueira:

We have been informed by Dr. P. S. Hench of the Mayo Clinic that the Cuban
Government is dedicating, on December 3, Camp Lazear, the place where Major
Walter Reed and his associates carried out their work on yellow fever in
1900. There are a great many civilian physicians and medical officers who
will be vitally interested in this project and who will be delighted indeed
to hear of this gracious gesture on the part of the Cuban Government. May
I, as Editor of the ____ ____, ask that you or your colleagues of the committee
send to me at your early convenience some information regarding the dedica-
tion which we can use in our journal, etc.”
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
How
General Albert Love
Colonel J. F. Siler
Page 2
November 4, 1952
P.S.: If the editors would prefer to write not to Doctor Nogueira but to
the Minister of Health himself, his name is Dr. Jose Raimundo Andreu, El
Ministro (the Minister) de Salubridad y Asistencia Social, or they could
write to the Public Relation Department of El Ministerio (the Ministry)
de Salubridad y Asistencia Social. If the editor does not receive a prompt
reply from Doctor Andreu directly, he might write to Dr. Nogueira, or vice
versa.
